unnormalised: ## Return to Sender: A Comedy of Errors (and Return Policies)
normalised: Return to Sender: A Comedy of Errors and Return Policies

unnormalised: Let's face it, shopping online is a gamble. You see a stunning Anarkali suit on Myntra, looking like a Bollywood dream, and end up with something that resembles your grandma's ill-fitting curtains. Or that “handcrafted” wooden elephant from a Jaipur-based Etsy shop turns out to be suspiciously plastic-y. What then, my friends? What then?

unnormalised: This is where the glorious, sometimes baffling, world of Return Policies enters the picture. Some are smoother than butter chicken at Moti Mahal, others are… well, let’s just say dealing with them is more stressful than attempting to parallel park in Chandni Chowk.

unnormalised: Take, for instance, that time I ordered a rug from a website promising "easy 30-day returns." Turns out, "easy" meant filling out a form longer than the Ramayana, printing a shipping label requiring a printer (who even *owns* a printer these days?), and then trekking to the nearest Blue Dart office, which, naturally, was located 20 km away in peak Delhi heat. All for a rug that shed more fibers than a Himalayan sheepdog in summer.

unnormalised: Then there’s the classic "conditions apply" scenario. The website boasts “Full refund if unsatisfied!” but buried deep in the fine print, next to the terms and conditions about data privacy and alien abduction, is a clause stating the item must be returned in its original packaging, undamaged, and under the precise lunar phase during which it was purchased. Good luck with that, Rajesh!

unnormalised: And don’t even get me started on "store credit only." You return a shirt that shrunk 3 sizes after one wash, only to be given store credit which you then promptly spend on more clothes that will inevitably also betray you. It’s a vicious cycle, like getting stuck in traffic on the Bandra-Worli Sea Link during rush hour.

unnormalised: Moral of the story? Read the Return Policy, people! Dr. Sharma always said, "Prevention is better than cure." A few minutes spent scrutinizing the fine print can save you hours of frustration, Rs. 500 in auto rickshaw fares, and a whole lot of unnecessary stress. And maybe, just maybe, you'll finally find that perfect saree that actually fits. Or a wooden elephant that isn't made of cheap plastic and takes up 10 sq ft of your living room.
